Part of set up is telling it your ZIP code, so it knows the weather (and can tell you) so it anticipates how hard the system needs to work to heat or cool and whether it will need to be on AC or Heat. iPhone app is a breeze and well thought out.

Since getting the Nest, I've also purchased some WeMo devices and they all work together well. The WeMo app found the Next thermostat on our network and now I can use the single iPhone app to control all of that (don't have to go back to the Nest app if I don't want to). Haven't gotten the Amazon Echo/Dot but that's likely next and will make using these devices even easier.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2016
Data:
Easy setup (read below if you have a two wire system without a C (common) wire), awesome interface, top notch quality, what else can I say? Love that I can control so many features from my laptop and smartphone. I also have three Nest Protect smoke and CO detectors which are monitored by the same app. Nest/Google hit not just a home run, but a grand slam out of the park with these two products.

-------------------

If you have a conventional two-wire system like me (Rc and W1), this is exactly what you need to get your smart thermostat working!

When I removed my Honeywell digital thermostat (non wifi), it had only two leads connected: Rc and W1. Not knowing anything about the latest generation of wifi thermostats, I went ahead and ordered the Nest Pro Gen III thermostat. Upon setup, I ran into two codes; e73 and e74. Essentially, they had to do with no power going to the unit. my VIN and VOC were 2.50 so I dug around on the internet, which led me to this transformer.

One lead went to C (24v common) and the other to Rh (see my photo of the interface's digital connection diagram). You may need to swap between Rc and Rh if you still have a error code readout. After plugging in the transformer, the VIN AND VOC read 34.17!!! Remember to plug this transformer into a surge protected outlet to prevent a possible damaged thermostat.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2023
Data:
March 2024 update: Removed 2 stars. Reason 1. The app frequently wants me to log in again. A real pain. The checkin requires me to turn on cookies and allow Javascript both of which comprises my security. In addition I greatly dislike Google’s constant spying on mre. Reason 2. I cannot turn off the Greenies programmed into the app that constantly want to invade my thermostat settings and influence what I buy.

This is the fourth one I have installed n my house. It is fairly easy to set up. The app is really good.

The thermostat as it clearly states in the description requires the C wire. However, if you have a two wire system, you can purchase an optional device that connects at the furnace and allows the thermostat to function with only two wires.

I am using this with a three remote sensors ($100 for 3 on Amazon) in my upstairs. The thermostat itself is mounted in the hall. A sensor is mounted in a different bedroom. On the app, you can see all four temperatures. The awesome feature is that the main thermostat or any one of the sensors can be chosen as the control for the temperature. One of my bedrooms runs cooler than the rest so the sensor in this bedroom is the controlling temperature.

Another feature I like is that it lights up when a person walks near it. This feature makes it easy for my wife or I to find our way to the bathroom in the middle of the night. The light is dim enough such that the sleeping partner is not disturbed.

The remote control from anywhere on the internet is a great feature as well. If you go away, you can control the thermostat from anywhere.

The learning feature works well although once in a while if we are too inactive watching tv in the evening it suddenly starts getting cold. I would not change this feature, because it can save a lot of fuel. I can put up with unintended cooling once in a while.

Making a temperatures setpoint change manually is very easy…spin the dial cw for increase or ccw for decrease.

Setting schedules is easy on the app and a little cumbersome on the dial, but possible and reasonable. I like the ability to copy one day’s schedule to another day. Given we are retired, I made one schedule, copied it and pasted it sx more times.

When you walk near the thermostat, the setpoint and actual temperature display. The setpoint is easy to see from ten feet away, to see the current temperature you need to be at normal reading distance…about three feet for me.

Being made by Google, I suspect that more data than I wish is being collected and added to thier database. I elected to minimize my exposure by putting the thermostats on my guest WiFi which limits any access to my sensitive equipment such as my computer. As a retired security industry guy, that you place all home control devices such as tv streamers (Firestick, Hulu, Apple TV, etc), appliances, power plug controllers, etc. on the guest WiFi as well. Most modern routers allow for at least one guest network.

Data:
I've been waiting to write this, because I wanted to give the thermostat some time to "learn". After living with it for over a year I can say there are two things I like about the thermostat, the look, and the ability to operate it remotely.
I have an irregular on-call/travel schedule so I am not home for set times and dates from week to week, but when I am home I don't want to worry about the thermostat changing the temperature for me. Depending on the settings, the Nest will eventually learn what times it thinks it needs to turn on/off Heating/AC and then start changing the temperature on it's own. Even if you're home and override that by setting it to a different temperature, it will change the temperature all on it's own. Eventually I got tired of fighting it and set the thermostat to manual mode. The learning/schedule might be better for someone that is home for set times/days throughout the week/month. I can't seem to get mine to run the fan only mode without turning on the AC or Heat. If you want to turn on the FAN only for your central air, after the fan runs for a pre-determined amount of time it will run the heat/ac as it sees fit.
The remote access feature is nice when it works. When I first set it up I registered it with an email address I use for login type memberships. I loaded the app on my phone and it worked great for the fist few months. Eventually my login stopped working and I was unable to remote operate my thermostat. When I contacted Nest support they told me I had to create and use a "Google" account to log in. I explained that I had been using another email account to log in for months and they advised that I was no longer allowed to use a different email because it's a google product and they're not going to change that. So now I have a google account that I really only created and use for this silly thermostat.

Data:
Installed two of thee in my RV and they are working great. The wiring for the original Thermostats was 12vdc, which is what is sent to signal the AC. I had to provide 24vac to the Nest since that is what it requires. This was done with $13 24vac transformer. I then had to turn that back into 12vdc. I did this with a set of 4 relays. The end result works great and its a huge upgrade from the original slide type thermostat, which was not accurate on temperature at all and had my AC running much longer than necessary.

My only complaint so far about this device is the restrictions on the Farsight feature. The display can obviously show multiple lines, you can tell that with the weather option, which shows a large number for current outside temp and then three smaller temps below that for later in the day. They could easily show the inside and target temp as well as fan speed all on one screen.

Be warned that in most cases you cannot just swap out your existing RV Thermostat with the Nest. Check what voltage and whether its AC or DC at your current thermostat first. If its not 24vac then you will need other components.

Installed easy. Then it had a blowout of some sort. Had to get a replacement. Nest recommended to call a technician, which I did and he found nothing wrong. Nest then had me add a common wire, and since that time has worked, sort of worked.

While it does work as a thermostat, the advanced features of power saving are not very good. I find that I must walk by this thermostat so that it will turn on the AC. If I'm home but don't walk by it the house slowly warms. I've set specific schedules and it sort of conforms to them, at the points set (time and temp) but not necessarily between those points.

So overall, it wasn't a simple install due to the additional wire that they claimed in the beginning wouldn't be needed, but was. Nest did offer to pay for the common wire to be installed though (I installed it myself).

I wouldn't recommend this, it's just too costly, had problems, and just doesn't work right without constant manual intervention.

It does however seem to work mostly as a manual thermometer, at least when someone is home and willing to walk by it frequently. Else it doesn't work.

For instance, at times I want it to maintain a temperature, and it won't. Yeah, just reading this makes me knock it down another star to two. It's at best a 2 star product, but mostly hype and marketing, without much substance.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2022
Data:
I’ve had my Nest thermostat for over a year and was SHOCKED to find my energy costs going UP and increased maintenance required on my Lennox Furnace system.

I spent so much money on this system because I thought it was “smart,” but honestly it’s got some of the dumbest, unintuitive features and settings.

I started paying more attention to why my furnace was working so hard and found out it was short-cycling. Meaning that even though I have my furnace on a schedule, the heat clicks on throughout the day for about 1 minute, shuts off for 2-3 min, then turns BACK on for another min, and so on. (The schedule I have set is supposed to heat to 68 degrees at 9 am then drops to a set temperature of 62 degrees during the day, then heats back to 68 degrees at 6 pm and drops to a set temperature of 62 degrees overnight - sidenote: if you choose to set a temperature schedule through the nest, you can’t set a different temperature on the schedule within an hour of the initial set temperature, otherwise I would have my house heat to 68 at 9 am and then drop to 62 at 9:30 am, but no, the earliest I can set the next, lower temperature, is 10 am, a full hour after the house heats and has been maintaining the initial set temperature, so dumb!)

After I realized my system was short-cycling due to the nest thermostat, I spent hours searching through convoluted “help” articles from Nest. This is how I found out that the thermostat is constantly trying to heat the house and keep it set to the TENTH OF A DEGREE. Meaning that if I set my thermostat to heat to 68 degrees, the thermostat will assign a temperature of 68.6 degrees Fahrenheit. After it heats to that temperature, anytime it drops down to 68.5 degrees Fahrenheit, the whole system clicks on and heats the house back up to 68.6 degrees. Ideally, you’d be able to set the “hysteresis” or a timer on the thermostat (especially on a $200+ thermostat equipment) so that the temperature could be set to something like 72 degrees, heat to that temperature, and then not switch back on to heat the house for a set period of time or until the temperature in the house drops to a certain temperature like 68 degrees.

This lack of intuitive settings on the Nest is costing me a FORTUNE between furnace maintenance and increased energy costs (kind of crazy when the Nest is supposed to be so “eco friendly”!) and I’m considering switching back to my $15 Honeywell thermostat which is insane. Until they add this feature to the Nest thermostat, I warn you to steer away from this equipment!

Data: One year ago, I purchased the Nest Thermostat as the exterior of the Nest was a good design and I mistakenly thought the expensive Nest would work well for my family in our home. The most important fact about the Nest Thermostat is an understanding and the acceptance, prior to buying, the buyer is not in control of the thermostat. The term "learn" is exactly what the Nest is and that's when all the good stuff will turn sour and in only a day or two. After a day or two, then, let's say, you have a really cold day and it is chilly inside too; you turn the Nest Thermostat up a few degrees, a note will pop up on the face of the Nest and will indicates in 2.5 hours the heat may not even turn on 2.5 hours. The Nest will decide the owner is not being a good steward in our Eco world and decide for you to not turn on and, regardless, of what you try to do, the heat will not come on so your heater may take the chill out of the air. Also, if the home is extra warm in the summer, you'll experience the same delay. The Nest is the boss and it will let you immediately know that fact. Sometimes, the delay is a little less and also a little more but you'll realize, you, the buyer, are not in control of your home's thermostat and your indoor temperatures. The Nest determines what is best for the buyer and the environment and there is no way to change the learning factor and according to the Nest tech's, with whom I spoke, they finally tell me what I have learned is a fact...you are not in control of your thermostat. Now the expensive Nest Thermostat sits in a box in storage and, yesterday, I purchased a simple, logical, programmable thermostat.

I received the Nest thermostat as a gift 7 years now. I stopped using the learning features and just set the schedule manually. I did this because the "learning" is actually pretty stoopid. I found that all it does is update the schedule any time I made a temperature change. For example, if at 3:00 PM on Tuesday, I changed the temperature to 73F, it would add to the schedule to set the temperature to 73F every Tuesday at 3:00 PM. That's not "smart".

It has access to current conditions like weather/outdoor temperature and humidity (via the internet), indoor temperature and indoor humidity. Why doesn't it learn from that and track those conditions and adjust the temperature based on what it's seen?

I also don't see any benefit of the "cool to dry" feature. It really doesn't do anything unless the indoor humidity reaches and unhealthy level (it doesn't seem to care about it being at a comfortable level).

I'm not up to date on newer versions and what other companies offer. I think it's time to start shopping.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2023
Data:
March 2024 update: Removed 2 stars. Reason 1. The app frequently wants me to log in again. A real pain. The checkin requires me to turn on cookies and allow Javascript both of which comprises my security. In addition I greatly dislike Google’s constant spying on mre. Reason 2. I cannot turn off the Greenies programmed into the app that constantly want to invade my thermostat settings and influence what I buy.

This is the fourth one I have installed n my house. It is fairly easy to set up. The app is really good.

The thermostat as it clearly states in the description requires the C wire. However, if you have a two wire system, you can purchase an optional device that connects at the furnace and allows the thermostat to function with only two wires.

I am using this with a three remote sensors ($100 for 3 on Amazon) in my upstairs. The thermostat itself is mounted in the hall. A sensor is mounted in a different bedroom. On the app, you can see all four temperatures. The awesome feature is that the main thermostat or any one of the sensors can be chosen as the control for the temperature. One of my bedrooms runs cooler than the rest so the sensor in this bedroom is the controlling temperature.

Another feature I like is that it lights up when a person walks near it. This feature makes it easy for my wife or I to find our way to the bathroom in the middle of the night. The light is dim enough such that the sleeping partner is not disturbed.

The remote control from anywhere on the internet is a great feature as well. If you go away, you can control the thermostat from anywhere.

The learning feature works well although once in a while if we are too inactive watching tv in the evening it suddenly starts getting cold. I would not change this feature, because it can save a lot of fuel. I can put up with unintended cooling once in a while.

Making a temperatures setpoint change manually is very easy…spin the dial cw for increase or ccw for decrease.

Setting schedules is easy on the app and a little cumbersome on the dial, but possible and reasonable. I like the ability to copy one day’s schedule to another day. Given we are retired, I made one schedule, copied it and pasted it sx more times.

When you walk near the thermostat, the setpoint and actual temperature display. The setpoint is easy to see from ten feet away, to see the current temperature you need to be at normal reading distance…about three feet for me.

Being made by Google, I suspect that more data than I wish is being collected and added to thier database. I elected to minimize my exposure by putting the thermostats on my guest WiFi which limits any access to my sensitive equipment such as my computer. As a retired security industry guy, that you place all home control devices such as tv streamers (Firestick, Hulu, Apple TV, etc), appliances, power plug controllers, etc. on the guest WiFi as well. Most modern routers allow for at least one guest network.

I can't seem to get mine to run the fan only mode without turning on the AC or Heat. If you want to turn on the FAN only for your central air, after the fan runs for a pre-determined amount of time it will run the heat/ac as it sees fit.
The remote access feature is nice when it works. When I first set it up I registered it with an email address I use for login type memberships. I loaded the app on my phone and it worked great for the fist few months. Eventually my login stopped working and I was unable to remote operate my thermostat. When I contacted Nest support they told me I had to create and use a "Google" account to log in. I explained that I had been using another email account to log in for months and they advised that I was no longer allowed to use a different email because it's a google product and they're not going to change that. Data:
The Nest is nice and modern and I can control most features with the Nest App or Alexa, but there is room for improvement in its features. I’d give it 3 1/2 stars right now.
The schedule is a good feature (but common in smart thermostats now); I like that it tells us the humidity level in the house, which I imagine will be more important in winter.
The learning feature seems good (even if I’m impatient that it seemed to take a while to realize that we don’t want to freeze through summer nights).
But Nest missing some features that our previous thermostat had:
-Nest only displays the temperature it’s set for. It does not give you the current temperature in the house. It’s important to know the ambient temp so that I can set it accordingly.
-I can’t turn the fan on or off from Alexa.
-I can’t turn the fan off from the Nest App (can only turn it on).
-The Eco temperatures take over, which can sometimes be bad. Eco gradually raises or lowers the temperature over hours, which is bad when It’s working harder than you need at the moment.
For instance after a hot summer day, in the evening when it cools down outside, ECO still blasts the air conditioning inside so that we’re freezing at like 10pm. It’s not enough to raise the temp in the app, b/c ECO will take hours to transition. We have to turn the thermostat and fan to “off” b/c it doesn’t make sense to have to sleep under multiple blankets in the middle of a heat wave waiting for ECO mode to eventually stop blowing cold air.
-The NEST also gave a wiring error twice after I shut off the air conditioner and fan on 2 nights when it was freezing us out. We had an electrician come Re-do the wiring after the first error message. He said the wiring looked fine but he followed Nest’s instructions to be certain the wiring wasn’t the issue... but then when the same error happened again in the same circumstance, I realized it must be a glitch when you shut it all off suddenly.

Nest could fix these issues with a software upgrade. I hope they do.
If so, I increase my rating to 5 stars.

Data: First, let me state that this device is beautiful and I love the interface. However, if you are using this to automatically control humidity, you should probably reconsider because: this "smart" thermostat DOES NOT factor in outdoor air temperature adjusting the humidity level. As the outside air temperature drops, indoor humidity as percentage should also drop to avoid moisture levels that are too high. If you live in a place with temperature swings (i.e. places where it snows), you may need to adjust humidity settings several times per week (if not per day) to maintain appropriate humidity levels inside the house. With the Nest, you have to constantly do this manually. Given that the Nest obtains outside temperatures through the internet, it seems it should easily be able to add the auto-adjusting feature for humidity. If you're in the market for a smart thermostat and want it hooked up to a whole house humidifier, look to the Ecobee or something else which can appropriately maintain humidity. This has been a complaint of Nest users for years. Apparently a third party app was developed to address the humidity issue, but Google put a stop to this. Think of this way: Nobody buys a car based on windshield wipers, but would anyone buy one without them? If something basic and essential is missing from a device, skip it. I will have to put my Nest up for sale and buy something more useful unless Google provides a fix . . . quickly.

Data:
I bought and installed this and was generally really happy with it for about five years. It worked great. After the fifth year, for some reason, my heater kept running and running, even when it wasn't hot. In fact, when it was supposed to be cooling it would still be heating. Many times, my temperature got up to about 90º F. Nothing would work.

After a lot of annoyance, I reset the thermostat and added it again, and the thermostat shut off the heat and started working again. It was okay for less than a day and then it started again. I came home, and found my home at about 90ºF last night. I looked it up, and apparently it seems to have something to do with the battery wearing out after that amount of time. It's fine, but I wish I'd known to expect it when I bought it. I was annoyed, but I went out to Target and bought a replacement at the store(the exact same model).

From the moment I popped the new thermostat on, I knew that it was working, because not only did my heater not keep on, but my air conditioner immediately turned on, and it turned the temperature down. I hadn't really felt that during the last year. I think the old thermostat was just turning on the blower but not the AC. I was really tired, and I fell asleep on top of my blankets. I woke up with the house at about 65º F, which is colder than I like my home, but it's the default for this model. I was cold, but I was overjoyed to have my home thermostat working again. I set it to my preferred temperature and went about my day. As of right now, my home's temperature is very comfortable.

These thermostats are good, for about five years. I have had mine for about six years. The new one uses the exact same base, so replacing it was as simple as popping the old one off of the mount and popping the new one on. Replacement took about 30 seconds, and then using the app to tell it to look for the new thermostat. This IS actually a very nice thermostat, but know that if you get it there's a good chance you'll be getting another one in about five years.

Data:
CYA, I am not liable and I suggest you consult a professional, qualified HVAC:

Our house has two floors. We have 2 A/C units outside and 2 furnaces. The attic has a furnace that controls upstairs and the upstairs has a furnace that controls the first level. The upstairs is not working correctly so turned off the attic furnace and only use the downstairs heating to heat the whole house. This is not efficient and also makes our furnace work overtime. We had an old Honeywell circle thermostat (mercury, mechanical) and bought a Nest. I followed Nest's instructions and while the A/C worked, the heater kept cycling (on for 2 seconds, off for 2 seconds) over and over again. I watched multiple YouTube videos on how to remove wires at the furnace board and jump wires and also how to move thermostat G to C...nothing worked. Our thermostat kept cycling on and off. We called Nest and they said our system is faulty. I did not believe that. We have a 4-wire setup (W1, Y1, RH (or RC), and G). After calling Nest, they concluded our HVAC was faulty. I knew it wasn't. I then watched more YouTube videos for removing wires and then jumping one to another (which worked to pass the test) but then didn't work when using the Nest. After we confirmed that the fan would turn on (YouTube video suggestion) we tried using the Nest as it should be used. Nope. We confirmed the fan works but that the Nest, despite stating it does not need a (C) common wire to work, still did not work properly. Long story short, I bought a 18/2 50-ft thermostat wire at a big box store, used just the white (technically, you can use any color as long as it is the same wire), turned of all power to the furnace and A/C, connected it to the C on the furnace board (works for most furnaces newer than 2010 or that pass the previously mentioned YouTube video test), and connected the other end of the wire to the Nest in the (C). Once connected and fully put back together (furnaces often have a button that dis-enable it unless the unit is put back together or the button is depressed), it now works 100% fine. Other smart thermostats can work without a (C), and Nest says it can too, however; in my experience customer service is not accurace and if you live in a home that has the old mercury/lead circle thermometer (aka, nothing is digital) and you have just 2 or 4 wires, and you want to use a Nest, you'll likely need to buy a $10-$15 50-foot 18/2 Thermostat wire and use one of them to connect the furnace (C) to the Nest (C).

Data:
The Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation offers all the learning and auto-scheduling features that earlier models had as well, upgraded to a slimmer design, Bluetooth support, and geofencing technology though. The Auto-Schedule feature that learns your daily heating and cooling temperatures and times during the first week of use and creates a schedule based on your preferences.
It is very easy to install. I just connected the red and green wires to the Rh and Rc (power) terminals, the white wire to the W1 (heat) terminal, and the blue wire to the C (common) terminal and it started working. Some personal configurations as setting it up with the WiFi signal and all is done. It works with multiple third-party devices and supports voice commands via Google Home and Amazon's Alexa voice service as well! The thermostat is also equipped with 802.11b/g/n (2.4GHz) and 802.11a/n (5GHz) Wi-Fi circuitry, a Bluetooth radio, and 512MB of memory. It works with most 24V heating and cooling systems. It supports three-stage heating, two-stage cooling, three-speed fans, and humidifier and dehumidifier add-ons. What’s definitely cool is that it uses motion sensors to detect your presence and it will switch to ECO (energy conservation) mode automatically if it thinks you are not home.
Design wise it comes in black, white, stainless steel, or copper finish and it has a large display (2.1”) with a high resolution (480 by 480). That allows you to see the display throughout a large room without a problem.

Data:
Easy setup (read below if you have a two wire system without a C (common) wire), awesome interface, top notch quality, what else can I say? Love that I can control so many features from my laptop and smartphone. I also have three Nest Protect smoke and CO detectors which are monitored by the same app. Nest/Google hit not just a home run, but a grand slam out of the park with these two products.

-------------------

If you have a conventional two-wire system like me (Rc and W1), this is exactly what you need to get your smart thermostat working!

When I removed my Honeywell digital thermostat (non wifi), it had only two leads connected: Rc and W1. Not knowing anything about the latest generation of wifi thermostats, I went ahead and ordered the Nest Pro Gen III thermostat. Upon setup, I ran into two codes; e73 and e74. Essentially, they had to do with no power going to the unit. my VIN and VOC were 2.50 so I dug around on the internet, which led me to this transformer.

One lead went to C (24v common) and the other to Rh (see my photo of the interface's digital connection diagram). You may need to swap between Rc and Rh if you still have a error code readout. After plugging in the transformer, the VIN AND VOC read 34.17!!! Remember to plug this transformer into a surge protected outlet to prevent a possible damaged thermostat.

Installed two of thee in my RV and they are working great. The wiring for the original Thermostats was 12vdc, which is what is sent to signal the AC. I had to provide 24vac to the Nest since that is what it requires. This was done with $13 24vac transformer. I then had to turn that back into 12vdc. I did this with a set of 4 relays. The end result works great and its a huge upgrade from the original slide type thermostat, which was not accurate on temperature at all and had my AC running much longer than necessary.

My only complaint so far about this device is the restrictions on the Farsight feature. The display can obviously show multiple lines, you can tell that with the weather option, which shows a large number for current outside temp and then three smaller temps below that for later in the day. They could easily show the inside and target temp as well as fan speed all on one screen.

Be warned that in most cases you cannot just swap out your existing RV Thermostat with the Nest. Check what voltage and whether its AC or DC at your current thermostat first. If its not 24vac then you will need other components.

I received the Nest thermostat as a gift 7 years now. I stopped using the learning features and just set the schedule manually. I did this because the "learning" is actually pretty stoopid. For example, if at 3:00 PM on Tuesday, I changed the temperature to 73F, it would add to the schedule to set the temperature to 73F every Tuesday at 3:00 PM. That's not "smart".

It has access to current conditions like weather/outdoor temperature and humidity (via the internet), indoor temperature and indoor humidity. Why doesn't it learn from that and track those conditions and adjust the temperature based on what it's seen?

I also don't see any benefit of the "cool to dry" feature. It really doesn't do anything unless the indoor humidity reaches and unhealthy level (it doesn't seem to care about it being at a comfortable level).

I'm not up to date on newer versions and what other companies offer. I think it's time to start shopping.

Data: After years of wrestling with the product, I conclude the highest and best use of the Nest Learning Thermostat is as a hockey puck. The customer support is horrible. The software, user interface and functioning is much more complex than necessary. At the same time, the device will not perform simple basic functions like hold at a set temperature if you have programed a schedule. The only way to set the thermostat at a fixed temperature is to erase the schedule. This requires tediously re-creating a new schedule to use scheduling again. The learning aspect of the thermostat is primitive, illogical and completely useless. I can save energy much more effectively than a Nest thermostat. The worse function is that somehow the thermostat turns itself down when I need heat the most. An example is on an early, dark, cold winter morning getting out of the shower when the bathroom should be warming but IS NOT. After being set low all night according to my programed schedule, I sent the time to turn on and call for heat. Oh no! A little message appears and says something like, "Peek Time" and the temperature is automatically set lower by Nest software. This is the fourth one I have installed n my house. It is fairly easy to set up. The app is really good.

The thermostat as it clearly states in the description requires the C wire. However, if you have a two wire system, you can purchase an optional device that connects at the furnace and allows the thermostat to function with only two wires.

I am using this with a three remote sensors ($100 for 3 on Amazon) in my upstairs. The thermostat itself is mounted in the hall. A sensor is mounted in a different bedroom. On the app, you can see all four temperatures. The awesome feature is that the main thermostat or any one of the sensors can be chosen as the control for the temperature. One of my bedrooms runs cooler than the rest so the sensor in this bedroom is the controlling temperature.

Another feature I like is that it lights up when a person walks near it. This feature makes it easy for my wife or I to find our way to the bathroom in the middle of the night. The light is dim enough such that the sleeping partner is not disturbed.

The remote control from anywhere on the internet is a great feature as well. If you go away, you can control the thermostat from anywhere.

The learning feature works well although once in a while if we are too inactive watching tv in the evening it suddenly starts getting cold. I would not change this feature, because it can save a lot of fuel. I can put up with unintended cooling once in a while.

Making a temperatures setpoint change manually is very easy…spin the dial cw for increase or ccw for decrease.

Setting schedules is easy on the app and a little cumbersome on the dial, but possible and reasonable. I like the ability to copy one day’s schedule to another day. Given we are retired, I made one schedule, copied it and pasted it sx more times.

When you walk near the thermostat, the setpoint and actual temperature display. The setpoint is easy to see from ten feet away, to see the current temperature you need to be at normal reading distance…about three feet for me.

Being made by Google, I suspect that more data than I wish is being collected and added to thier database. I elected to minimize my exposure by putting the thermostats on my guest WiFi which limits any access to my sensitive equipment such as my computer. I bought and installed this and was generally really happy with it for about five years. It worked great. After the fifth year, for some reason, my heater kept running and running, even when it wasn't hot. In fact, when it was supposed to be cooling it would still be heating. Many times, my temperature got up to about 90º F. Nothing would work.

After a lot of annoyance, I reset the thermostat and added it again, and the thermostat shut off the heat and started working again. It was okay for less than a day and then it started again. I came home, and found my home at about 90ºF last night. I looked it up, and apparently it seems to have something to do with the battery wearing out after that amount of time. It's fine, but I wish I'd known to expect it when I bought it. I was annoyed, but I went out to Target and bought a replacement at the store(the exact same model).

From the moment I popped the new thermostat on, I knew that it was working, because not only did my heater not keep on, but my air conditioner immediately turned on, and it turned the temperature down. I hadn't really felt that during the last year. I think the old thermostat was just turning on the blower but not the AC. I was really tired, and I fell asleep on top of my blankets. I woke up with the house at about 65º F, which is colder than I like my home, but it's the default for this model. I was cold, but I was overjoyed to have my home thermostat working again. I set it to my preferred temperature and went about my day. As of right now, my home's temperature is very comfortable.

These thermostats are good, for about five years. I have had mine for about six years. The new one uses the exact same base, so replacing it was as simple as popping the old one off of the mount and popping the new one on. Replacement took about 30 seconds, and then using the app to tell it to look for the new thermostat. This IS actually a very nice thermostat, but know that if you get it there's a good chance you'll be getting another one in about five years.

Data:
I’ve had my Nest thermostat for over a year and was SHOCKED to find my energy costs going UP and increased maintenance required on my Lennox Furnace system.

I spent so much money on this system because I thought it was “smart,” but honestly it’s got some of the dumbest, unintuitive features and settings.

I started paying more attention to why my furnace was working so hard and found out it was short-cycling. Meaning that even though I have my furnace on a schedule, the heat clicks on throughout the day for about 1 minute, shuts off for 2-3 min, then turns BACK on for another min, and so on. (The schedule I have set is supposed to heat to 68 degrees at 9 am then drops to a set temperature of 62 degrees during the day, then heats back to 68 degrees at 6 pm and drops to a set temperature of 62 degrees overnight - sidenote: if you choose to set a temperature schedule through the nest, you can’t set a different temperature on the schedule within an hour of the initial set temperature, otherwise I would have my house heat to 68 at 9 am and then drop to 62 at 9:30 am, but no, the earliest I can set the next, lower temperature, is 10 am, a full hour after the house heats and has been maintaining the initial set temperature, so dumb!)

After I realized my system was short-cycling due to the nest thermostat, I spent hours searching through convoluted “help” articles from Nest. This is how I found out that the thermostat is constantly trying to heat the house and keep it set to the TENTH OF A DEGREE. Meaning that if I set my thermostat to heat to 68 degrees, the thermostat will assign a temperature of 68.6 degrees Fahrenheit. After it heats to that temperature, anytime it drops down to 68.5 degrees Fahrenheit, the whole system clicks on and heats the house back up to 68.6 degrees. Ideally, you’d be able to set the “hysteresis” or a timer on the thermostat (especially on a $200+ thermostat equipment) so that the temperature could be set to something like 72 degrees, heat to that temperature, and then not switch back on to heat the house for a set period of time or until the temperature in the house drops to a certain temperature like 68 degrees.

This lack of intuitive settings on the Nest is costing me a FORTUNE between furnace maintenance and increased energy costs (kind of crazy when the Nest is supposed to be so “eco friendly”!) and I’m considering switching back to my $15 Honeywell thermostat which is insane. Until they add this feature to the Nest thermostat, I warn you to steer away from this equipment!

Data:
Easy setup (read below if you have a two wire system without a C (common) wire), awesome interface, top notch quality, what else can I say? Love that I can control so many features from my laptop and smartphone. I also have three Nest Protect smoke and CO detectors which are monitored by the same app. Nest/Google hit not just a home run, but a grand slam out of the park with these two products.

-------------------

If you have a conventional two-wire system like me (Rc and W1), this is exactly what you need to get your smart thermostat working!

When I removed my Honeywell digital thermostat (non wifi), it had only two leads connected: Rc and W1. Not knowing anything about the latest generation of wifi thermostats, I went ahead and ordered the Nest Pro Gen III thermostat. Upon setup, I ran into two codes; e73 and e74. Essentially, they had to do with no power going to the unit. my VIN and VOC were 2.50 so I dug around on the internet, which led me to this transformer.

One lead went to C (24v common) and the other to Rh (see my photo of the interface's digital connection diagram). You may need to swap between Rc and Rh if you still have a error code readout. After plugging in the transformer, the VIN AND VOC read 34.17!!! Remember to plug this transformer into a surge protected outlet to prevent a possible damaged thermostat.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2023
Data:
March 2024 update: Removed 2 stars. Reason 1. The app frequently wants me to log in again. A real pain. The checkin requires me to turn on cookies and allow Javascript both of which comprises my security. In addition I greatly dislike Google’s constant spying on mre. Reason 2. I cannot turn off the Greenies programmed into the app that constantly want to invade my thermostat settings and influence what I buy.

This is the fourth one I have installed n my house. It is fairly easy to set up. The app is really good.

The thermostat as it clearly states in the description requires the C wire. However, if you have a two wire system, you can purchase an optional device that connects at the furnace and allows the thermostat to function with only two wires.

I am using this with a three remote sensors ($100 for 3 on Amazon) in my upstairs. The thermostat itself is mounted in the hall. A sensor is mounted in a different bedroom. On the app, you can see all four temperatures. The awesome feature is that the main thermostat or any one of the sensors can be chosen as the control for the temperature. One of my bedrooms runs cooler than the rest so the sensor in this bedroom is the controlling temperature.

Another feature I like is that it lights up when a person walks near it. This feature makes it easy for my wife or I to find our way to the bathroom in the middle of the night. The light is dim enough such that the sleeping partner is not disturbed.

The remote control from anywhere on the internet is a great feature as well. If you go away, you can control the thermostat from anywhere.

The learning feature works well although once in a while if we are too inactive watching tv in the evening it suddenly starts getting cold. I would not change this feature, because it can save a lot of fuel. I can put up with unintended cooling once in a while.

Making a temperatures setpoint change manually is very easy…spin the dial cw for increase or ccw for decrease.

Setting schedules is easy on the app and a little cumbersome on the dial, but possible and reasonable. I like the ability to copy one day’s schedule to another day. Given we are retired, I made one schedule, copied it and pasted it sx more times.

When you walk near the thermostat, the setpoint and actual temperature display. The setpoint is easy to see from ten feet away, to see the current temperature you need to be at normal reading distance…about three feet for me.

Being made by Google, I suspect that more data than I wish is being collected and added to thier database. I elected to minimize my exposure by putting the thermostats on my guest WiFi which limits any access to my sensitive equipment such as my computer. As a retired security industry guy, that you place all home control devices such as tv streamers (Firestick, Hulu, Apple TV, etc), appliances, power plug controllers, etc. on the guest WiFi as well. Most modern routers allow for at least one guest network.

Eventually I got tired of fighting it and set the thermostat to manual mode. The learning/schedule might be better for someone that is home for set times/days throughout the week/month. I can't seem to get mine to run the fan only mode without turning on the AC or Heat. If you want to turn on the FAN only for your central air, after the fan runs for a pre-determined amount of time it will run the heat/ac as it sees fit.
The remote access feature is nice when it works. When I first set it up I registered it with an email address I use for login type memberships. I loaded the app on my phone and it worked great for the fist few months. Eventually my login stopped working and I was unable to remote operate my thermostat. When I contacted Nest support they told me I had to create and use a "Google" account to log in. I explained that I had been using another email account to log in for months and they advised that I was no longer allowed to use a different email because it's a google product and they're not going to change that. The end result works great and its a huge upgrade from the original slide type thermostat, which was not accurate on temperature at all and had my AC running much longer than necessary.

My only complaint so far about this device is the restrictions on the Farsight feature. The display can obviously show multiple lines, you can tell that with the weather option, which shows a large number for current outside temp and then three smaller temps below that for later in the day. They could easily show the inside and target temp as well as fan speed all on one screen.

Be warned that in most cases you cannot just swap out your existing RV Thermostat with the Nest. Check what voltage and whether its AC or DC at your current thermostat first. If its not 24vac then you will need other components.
